repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Public Sector Management
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Public Sector
            Management Support Project is rated as unsatisfactory,
            sustainability as unlikely, institutional development impact
            as modest, Bank performance as unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance as unsatisfactory. The economic situation and
            political instability from 1993 to 1997 affected the
            implementation of the project. The key lessons learned from
            this project are: The project design should be simple. The
            components should reflect only the highest priorities of the
            Government and not lump together all desirable public sector
            issues to be resolved in one project in a country where
            implementation capacity is weak. There is a need for a
            review and revision of project design midstream by taking
            into consideration external circumstances. In a very weak
            institutional setting, it is important to limit the number
            of studies in a project because of inadequate capacity to
            implement the studies. It is also important to provide
            support to building capacity of local training institutions
            for the continuous training of the public service. In a
            post-conflict situation, the benefits can be large from not
            closing down completely a project that is supporting reform
            in public sector institutions, but leaving some modest
            amount of funds available to enable some state institutions
            to perform basic and vital functions in critical areas in
            order to minimize state failure.

18157520.theme: Public expenditure, financial management and procurement,Administrative and civil service reform,Debt management and fiscal sustainability
18157520.trustfund: TF023141-CANADA-SDA IN SSA II,TF032263-SIERRA LEONE - MACROECONOMICS

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Public Sector Management
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the project is
            to strengthen the government's capacity to implement
            its adjustment program and longer term growth strategy,
            focusing on fiscal management.  The project comprises
            emergency-type measures that need to be carried out as a
            first step in addressing the most pressing constraints to
            the effective implementation of the government's
            program of reforms.  It:  (a) focuses on agencies
            responsible for fiscal management:  (i) the Department of
            Finance, Development and Planning to strengthen budgeting,
            expenditure control, aid coordination, procurement and
            policy analysis; (ii) Accountant General's Office and
            Auditor General's Department to strengthen accounting,
            auditing, and control; and (iii) the establishment of
            capability in the Bank of Sierra Leone (BSL) to supervise
            disbursement of donor program support funds and strengthen
            BSL accounting capacity; (b) provides institutional support
            to:  (i) civil service reform to restore efficiency and
            capacity for delivery of services; (ii) public enterprise
            reform to reduce government ownership of public enterprises
            and improve the efficiency of those remaining in the public
            sector; (iii) build a capacity for supervision and
            regulation of the petroleum industry; and (iv) develop plans
            and work programs to address urgent social policy and
            poverty issues.
